Post Text: I said we should run meetings like this cartoon — and then, OMG, SOMEONE ACTUALLY DID IT!The background:I posted this New Yorker cartoon on LinkedIn last week, and said we should take it seriously.Why? Because when we put 30 or 60 minutes on the calendar, we blindly fill the time — even if we don’t need it.But constraints force focus. Obviously planks is a joke, but we’d do better with intentional forcing functions — like weirdly timed meetings (7 minutes!) or walk-and-talks.I hoped it would get people thinking — but I did NOT expect this response!O2E Brands founder Brian Scudamore sent me this photo from his office. “3 out of 3 agree — it actually works!!” he wrote.What great leadership... because no matter what happened, I bet they had fun. Post Text: What if we all acted more like this?Instead of saying “you’re doing it wrong” — we could say “here’s how to do it better.”This story is from 2018: A 13-year-old, Jaequan Faulkner, was running a hot dog stand, when someone called the cops because he didn’t have a permit.The city then helped the kid go legit — teaching him finance and marketing, and giving him a tent and a hand-washing station.He ended up selling hot dogs for years.Every day, we’re faced with a similar choice: A friend, colleague, or even stranger will stumble — and we can either tell them they’re wrong, or help them do better.When we choose the latter, we’re better too.Here’s another way to be better: My newsletter, One Thing Better, offers one way each week to improve your work — subscribe for free at jasonfeifer.com/newsletter

Post Text: Want to build the perfect product?Take a lesson from this 1800s automatic candle extinguisher...The best inventors and entrepreneurs think differently about problems!For example:When candles were a primary source of lighting, they also caused many fires and deaths.Tackling the problem of “fires” was huge and abstract. Post Text: How did Bozoma Saint John score high-profile jobs?This is CRITICAL: She negotiated how much *attention* she could get at each job.“I became an expert at negotiating how public-facing I can be on behalf of the company,” says Boz, who became well-known for her marketing and brand roles at Netflix, Apple, Uber, Endeavor, and PepsiCo.Her advice: “If you want to increase your value, that does not just come in your paycheck. When you are better known for the things you do, your value goes up. “Will this get you some haters? Yes, she says — but so what?“People still say I’m self-centered,” she says. “Well, if I’m not self-centered, who am I supposed to be centered on? Who? Please tell me it’s not you.”This resonates with me DEEPLY. People at past jobs complained that I got too much attention — but what would I get by becoming quieter? Author: Jason Feifer
Post Text: HOT TAKE — I think we should actually run meetings like this.Here’s why.You know Parkinson’s Law? It states that work expands to fit the time allowed.If you have lots of time to finish something, it’ll take a lot of time. If it’s a short deadline, you’ll do it faster.Meetings are the same. Put 30 or 60 minutes on the calendar, and we’ll fill that time — even if we don’t need it.Constraints force focus. Obviously doing planks is a joke — I’m not endorsing *that* — but we’d do better with intentional forcing functions.One idea: Some people plan meetings for short, weird amounts of time (7 minutes, say), because it focuses people on how to use the time best. It’s shifting meetings from “we’re here to talk” to “we’re here to get things done.”And with that, I’m done!👉 MAKE WORK BETTER! My newsletter, One Thing Better, can help. Post Text: Your 30-minute meetings can be done in 15 minutes.Research proves it — you must see this... Asana ran an experiment: It asked employees to wipe their calendars clean for two days... and then only add back the meetings that were truly useful. The result was surprising: People didn't just choose fewer meetings — they also cut the meeting times! Thirty-minute meetings became 15 minutes, and those meetings happened less frequently.  With this new cadence, people saved an average of 11 hours per month. That’s THREE AND A HALF WEEKS over the course of a year!Makes you wonder: How could YOUR time be better spent today?Want more smart ways to rethink your work? Post Text: Nobody wants to hear your success story — but here’s what they DO all want to hear.It’s your problem-solving story.It’s when you acknowledge how hard something is, and what you’re doing to get through it.That’s the relatable stuff. It’s the stuff that starts honest conversations. It’s also the stuff that builds trust.  As a magazine editor, I only interview people who share like this. I’ll never publish a story that’s only about someone’s success — because it’s not useful to the entrepreneurs reading it. Your peers won’t join you if you don’t talk about the hard stuff. They’ll just think you’re hiding something. Investors won’t trust you if you hide the hard stuff. They want to know your ability to navigate challenges.Success is about you. Challenges are about everyone. Live in that space.Here’s where I share the hard lessons I’ve learned — it’s my newsletter, jasonfeifer.com/newsletter

Post Text: I recently killed a story in Entrepreneur magazine.Why? Because of the publicist.This is a cautionary tale — and it goes far beyond PR. The backstory:I’d heard about a company that struggled and then made an interesting pivot. So I emailed a few questions — often my first step in deciding on a story.The company’s publicist sent answers, which all basically said: “Things are perfect! Nothing was ever wrong!”I was done. Why?Our readers are entrepreneurs, and they want real insights from others — which means those people must be open, vulnerable, and eager to share.The same is true for your customers — they want your honesty and humanity.Nobody is here for your talking points. Nobody wants to feel controlled or manipulated.My rule: When someone asks you something, don’t think “Here’s what I want them to think.” Instead, ask “What do they need to hear?”Want the answer to that? Post Text: This woman filmed herself getting laid off — and captured a DISASTER.Among the problems:❌ The call was with two jargon-speaking HR people she’d never met.❌ She was told she underperformed, but could not be given specifics.❌ She hadn’t been put on a performance review, and her manager only gave her positive feedback.This was at Cloudflare, and CEO Matthew Prince responded: “This video is painful for me to watch." (Full statement at https://lnkd.in/e8MwGXG2 )He acknowledged the mistakes: Managers should have been involved. No employee should be surprised they’re underperforming.Firing her wasn’t the mistake, he said — an org should know, within 3 months, whether a team member is the right fit.“We think the right thing to do is get people we know are unlikely to succeed off the team as quickly as possible so they can find the right place for them,” he wrote. “The mistake was not being more kind and human as we did.”What a terrible experience, but also an important conversation.Being fired sucks. Firing people sucks. I’ve been on both sides — awful each time!But it’s necessary — to build a healthy company, and to have a healthy career. So let’s strive to do this hard part with as much dignity and grace as possible.

Post Text: Despite what everyone says, you (and your brand) DO NOT need to be on every social media platform.I didn’t make this image — I just saw it trending on Instagram. You’ll just stretch yourself thin and post meaningless stuff for people who don’t care.Instead of trying to be everywhere, try to be MEANINGFUL. To start, ask yourself this:“Where are my people, what are my skills, and where can I naturally join the conversation?”Me, for example: My personal brand is aimed at professionals. I’m a fast writer (and a slow video editor), and I’m better in longform than shortform.That’s why I doubled down on LinkedIn (where I post daily) and newsletter (where I invest a lot of energy). I experiment on other platforms, but only on the margins.If you have the time and money, go ahead and post everywhere! But you don’t NEED TO. Your goal should be to connect with people, not just scroll past their eyeballs — and that means picking your spots and making it count.Want to reach people better? Author: Jason Feifer
Post Text: NEVER memorize a talk or presentation.Here’s why — a lesson from the WORST talk I’ve ever seen.I once saw a speaker at a conference. She was polished and well-paced, and the first few minutes were good.Then she stumbled on a word, and paused... for a FULL MINUTE.Then she repeated the previous sentence she'd said. Paused. Another silence.This happened repeatedly.I knew her problem.She'd memorized her talk word for word — so when she stumbled, she lost her place.To restart, she was literally re-running the script in her head. This is the danger of memorization. You're trapped inside your script, and one slip-up can derail you.Here’s how to do it better: Rehearse your material until you're comfortable. Fill it with stories and ideas you already know your way around. Memorize the structure, but never anchor yourself to the language.You don't want to read a script inside your head. You want to SPEAK — from your head and heart, to your audience's ears.Want to be more impactful? Post Text: Never send an email like this.A publicist sent me this — after I politely declined their pitch.And hey, I get it.We’re told “don’t take no for an answer!” and “persistence wins the day!”True — but you must do it right.If you got a “no” from someone, but you want to get a yes, then know this:🔥 Don’t tell someone they’re wrong. Post Text: Changes are coming to LinkedIn — and if you want to grow here, you should know about them.I got the inside look from LinkedIn’s editor in chief Daniel Roth and senior director of engineering Tim Jurka.LinkedIn is doubling down on incentivizing people to post “knowledge and advice” and to engage their focused professional communities — and continues to disincentivize broad efforts at virality.Among the ways it’s doing that:📈 A new “suggested post” feature will amplify your best posts for years — which LinkedIn hopes will incentivize people to post more useful, skill-specific content.🔁 Are you worried that, following last year’s algorithm changes, your reach on LinkedIn has shrunk? LinkedIn says that’s the wrong way to think about it. It wants to help you optimize reaching the *right* people.💻 It's adding more data and functionality to its newsletter product, and wants to compete directly against other newsletter platforms.🚀 “Creator mode” is coming for everyone (even as LinkedIn explicitly moves away from the term "creator"), company pages can now pay to promote other people’s posts, new “custom button” phrases will be rolling out (including one to promote newsletters), and more.And that’s just the start of my report with Entrepreneur Media!You can read it all here: https://lnkd.in/eMCuHz8P

Author: Jason Feifer
Post Text: I reached 100,000 followers yesterday — and here are the two contradictory ways I did it:1. CONSISTENCY + INCONSISTENCY I post every single day, and my tone is always the same — friendly and helpful. But I’m always trying new formats, ideas, and even writing structures. Not everything’s winner. I post a lot of duds! But the variety helps me identify new things that resonate, which I can then experiment more with, like... 2. UNORIGINAL + ORIGINAL Here’s something that worked well for me this year: I’d post images that already proved popular online — ads, cartoons, viral videos — but then add my own thoughtful analysis. My biggest hit: I posted an ad by the World Wildlife Federation, along with commentary on why it worked so well — and it got 13 MILLION impressions. You can’t just post viral nonsense; it won’t travel well here. Even if it does, you’re not seen as thoughtful (and what’s the point of just chasing numbers?) On LinkedIn, there *must* be value add — so think about how to grab people’s attention, and then honor that attention. Thank you to EVERYONE who follows me. It’s an honor to reach and exchange ideas with you, and there’s so much more to come! Want more ways to grow? Author: Jason Feifer
Post Text: Do you worry you ask too much of other people?I do — but Jimmy Fallon helped me think differently.Here’s the story.I once interviewed Jimmy for a cover profile in Entrepreneur. We met in his office at 30 Rock and had a great, insightful conversation.At the end, he invited me to reach out if I had follow-up questions. I said thanks, but that I’d already taken up a lot of his time and I wanted to respect that.And yet, as I started to write the story, I realized that I’d missed something important. I really DID need to follow up!“I really appreciate you squeezing this in,” I said to Jimmy when we reconnected.“No one ever takes me up on it!” Jimmy replied. “So I was like, yeah! He’s thorough, he’s smart. Let’s do it — I can’t wait.”“It’s so funny,” I replied, “because I think, oh, following up is a burden.”“Never,” Jimmy said.Let’s recap: Jimmy has been interviewed many times, and often offers to answer follow-up questions. Nobody takes him up on it, but I did. And to Jimmy, that wasn’t a burden — it was a sign of thoroughness.And he APPRECIATES thoroughness.Sometimes, the thing we think is a burden is actually an asset.But you’ll never know unless you ask.👉 What OTHER strengths are you missing? Post Text: Why would you share what you know — when others can just profit from it?This comment was left under a post of mine, after I said LinkedIn wants users to share “knowledge and advice.”I think this person is totally wrong. Here are 4 reasons to share what you know, freely and without expectation.1. THEIR SUCCESS IS NOT YOUR FAILURESuccess is not a zero-sum game. When people gain, you do not lose.In fact, when other people gain, YOU GAIN TOO — because they’ll remember who gave them that great insight, and will want to find some way to help you.2. YOUR IDEAS ARE NOT YOUR EXECUTIONYou know how to do something. But only YOU do it in your own unique way, and that’s where your success comes from.For example, I have many friends who want to be public speakers. I happily share what I’ve learned.I’m not protective of this information, because it’s just the foundations. I use that knowledge to give my talks in my style. They’ll use it to give their talks in their style. There’s no competition.3. YOU KNOW MORE THAN THAT!If you want someone to pay for your knowledge, you need to show them that you’re knowledgeable.If all your collective wisdom fits into a few LinkedIn posts, you might not have much worth paying for!4. YOU’RE PART OF A COMMUNITY (UNLESS YOU QUIT)Professionals on LinkedIn have built a beautiful social contract: We give, because we get. And if nobody gave, nobody would get.Yes, sure, you could be on here learning and never sharing. But what fun is that? I’m willing to give out ideas for free, because what I get in return is more valuable.AND I GIVE EVEN MORE right here in my newsletter — every week, one new way to be more successful and satisfied: jasonfeifer.com/newsletter

Post Text: Every speaker will face a person like this — and here’s how to handle it: Even though this person has “more of a comment than a question,” you treat them like they’re asking a question. Once you get the point they’re making, interrupt and say: “Thanks, sorry to cut you off, but you raise a great question there…” You’ve just validated something they said! They want to know what you’ll say next. You’ve also regained control and brought your audience back in. Now, reframe some small part of their “comment” as a question that you’re happy to answer. Like: “How can someone do X, given the problems with [whatever they were focused on]?” Then answer this question and move on! I picked this trick up by listening to NPR call-in shows, where the hosts have  mastered this verbal jiu-jitsu. Sometimes callers ramble, and the host always cuts in, reframes what they said as a coherent question, and poses that question to the show’s guest.Then the guest answers the question, and it’s on to the next.In short: Don’t lose control. Don’t push back. Don’t awkwardly try to move on. Just treat them like a questioner whose question was a little unclear, so you’re going to clarify it.Works every time!Want help navigating other tricky situations? Post Text: This person is setting goals all wrong.It’s a mistake I see WAY too often — and here’s why.A *LOT* of people send me stuff like this — telling me their goal is to be in Entrepreneur (especially on the cover).But goals should be things you have control over. Post Text: Here’s what LinkedIn “influencers” are earning for brand posts — and why you could, too.I just talked with my friend Brendan Gahan, who launched the world’s first LinkedIn-focused influencer marketing agency.He says LinkedIn is ripe with opportunity: B2B brands are interested in influencer marketing, and they like that LinkedIn “influencers” have potent, targeted audiences of professionals.So what can people charge for a post? Author: Jason Feifer
Post Text: Journalists keep insulting LinkedIn users and calling the site “cringe” — and as a media guy myself, I have a theory about why. A journalist’s professional experience is different from the average LinkedIn user, in three big ways: 1. Journalism is isolating. You report on other industries, which means you keep a distance from them — unlike the networking motivations of most LinkedIn users. 2. There’s little professional development architecture in journalism, so writers are unaccustomed to the kind of communications they see here. 3. As Business Insider’s Emily Stewart wrote of herself: “I don't want to come off as overly earnest, too self-promotional, or dare I say it, cringe.”That last one is worth unpacking. When I was purely a magazine writer/editor, I felt the same way.Earnestness and self-promotion are rarely encouraged in media. But they’re understood differently in much of the business world. It’s not earnestness; it’s relatability. It’s not self-promotion; it’s providing value to others. This thinking doesn’t come naturally — it’s learned through immersion.Obviously, there’s plenty of garbage on LinkedIn, just like any platform. Earnestness can be performative; self-promotion can be overdone. But like anything, it’s helpful to know where people are coming from... on both sides of any divide. I’d welcome my media peers to actually *participate* here, instead of just observe from afar. It feels very different once you join the conversation.(The Business Insider piece is here, should you be interested: https://lnkd.in/ex-ZCpR6)

Post Text: Everyone wants to be a better writer — but only ONE THING can actually help you do it. It isn’t some magic routine. It isn’t connections. It isn’t expensive this and thats. Here’s what makes you a better writer: WRITING. Do it often. Do it in public. Get critical feedback from people who push you to be sharper, more focused, and less verbose. When I began, I wrote for tiny blogs and newspapers. Editors would tell me to rewrite things. That hurt. But I’d do it. Then I’d publish — which changes everything. Once it’s in the world, it’s no longer yours. Now you see your writing through your readers’ eyes. You see all the flaws. All the ways you could have improved. Then you channel that into the next thing you write. And you repeat. Stop talking about the things you want to write. Actually start writing. It might be bad. Post Text: I got this card when I was 13 — by creating a sneaky way to get athletes’ signatures. First, I’d buy a pack of cards. Post Text: Here’s some weird public speaking advice —If you want to develop a killer keynote, the best tool you have comes RIGHT AFTER your talk.It’s in the feedback after a Q&A.Here's how I use this strategically:First, if an event allows it, make sure to do Q&As after your talk. Post Text: I once applied for a job at BuzzFeed — and the hiring manager told me, "We're reaching readers in the wrong way." It's a lesson I've thought about ever since.Some background:Back when BuzzFeed had a large newsroom, I'd applied to work in what they called their "Longform" (ie, long stories) section. But the editor told me they were eliminating the section, and integrating long stories into other sections. Why? Because although *journalists* often thought about content in terms of "longform," users did not. Nobody wakes up and says, "I want to read a long story." So BuzzFeed needed to re-organize — speaking in a way that USERS found relevant.You must do the same in our own work. Forget your language, or the way you understand your work. See your efforts through your future clients' eyes.What are THEY looking for? What language do THEY use? Author: Jason Feifer
Post Text: Here’s how I turn one keynote talk into infinite customized talks.It all starts with this: I built my talk modularly.For context: I speak to many different audiences, who have many different needs. Making a new talk for everyone is impossible — but I want to serve every client uniquely.A modular structure fixes that. The intro and outro are the same (and I improvise personalization for each audience). Then the meat of the talk is built on modules.Each module is about 7-12 minutes long. I start each with a big idea, then tell a compelling story to illustrate it, then offer a takeaway and exercise.Over time, I add, refine, and retire modules. I have five active ones now, and maybe 10 that I've retired.When I’m hired to speak, I do an intro call with the client to learn about the audience, their needs, and their interests. Based on that, as well as how much time I have on stage (30 minutes? 45? 60?), I assemble the talk.Maybe I’ll use the intro, plus modules 1, 2, 4, and 5, and then the outro — and no Q&A.Maybe I’ll use the intro, plus modules 2, 3, and 4, and then the outro — and 15 min of Q&A.Or whatever. A talk easily snaps into place.In my notes, I also give myself suggestions of how each module connects to a certain audience need. For example: If they’re going through X, then I can relate that to a point I make in Module 2.As a result, I have one talk that can be used and delivered in infinite ways — giving me more opportunities to work with clients, but with a lot less work.Want to be more strategic about YOUR work? Post Text: Want to be a better storyteller? Get to know the “e structure” of stories — and you’ll hook your audience early! How does it work? Well… imagine drawing a lower-case “e”. First, you draw a line forward. Then you curve up and BEHIND where you started, and carry forward. That’s how to tell the story: Start in the middle, back up to the beginning, reach where you started, and get to the end. Magazine features usually follow this format. So do many TV shows and movies. People love stories, but they always want to know: “Where’s this going? Will I care?” That's why the e structure works — by answering your audience's questions at the start! You’re saying: “Here’s where this is going, and yes, you’ll love it.” Now they want to know more! 👉 Want to upgrade your work in small, smart ways? Post Text: This formula is amazing — it shows EXACTLY how much you should pay someone to help you.I learned it from Dan Martell, who calls it the “buy back rate” — the amount of money you should pay to buy back your time.It goes like this:First, calculate how much you make in a year. Divide that by 2,000, which is the average amount of work hours in a year.Now you have your hourly value. Let’s say you make $50 / hr.Now divide that by 4 — because if you pay someone to free up your time, Dan says, you should get at least 4 times ROI on that spend. In this case, that’s $12.50.“If you're making $50 an hour, you wouldn't want to trade it for another $50 an hour,” Dan says. “You want to trade it for $12.50 an hour task so that you could then go do more of the $50-an-hour type activities.”That’s just the start — I had a fascinating conversation with him on my podcast Help Wanted, where we dig deep on when, how, and why to pay for help. Listen: https://lnkd.in/eX6FebNn

Post Text: Obsessing over a mistake?Try this exercise — it'll help you feel better: Try to remember the last time someone you know messed up in a similar way. For example, did you say something awkward in a conversation, and now you’re beating yourself up over it? Post Text: Have you fallen into a “spam trap”?I had no idea this existed — but it can kill your email list!Here’s what it is...A spam trap looks like any ol’ email address — like, let’s say, jasonf596019@gmail.com. But this address was created as a trap.It was placed on blogs and web forums, but NEVER used to subscribe to a newsletter.So what happens if a newsletter or marketer emails it? Now an ISP knows: That email writer uses bad tactics — like scraping the web or buying addresses in bulk — because there’s no other way this address could get on their list.Once the ISP knows that, the newsletter may be treated as spam — because when you fall for a spam trap, you BECOME spam.And that’s not the only way to fall for a spam trap. Sometimes someone just mis-types their email address (writing gmial instead of gmail) and it might get flagged as spam.This is why I partnered with ZeroBounce — a company that helps people make more money from email, by improving their email reach.
